wide cavern of his mouth, a pulsing mass of blood and teeth. And,
with it all, he made attempts to cry out. In his endeavor there
was a dreadful earnestness as if he concieved that one great
shriek would make him well.
FlemingThe youth saw him presently go rearward. His strength
seemed in no wise impaired. He ran swiftly casting wild
glances for succor.
Others fell down nabout their compathe feet of
their companions. Some of the wounded crawled out and
away, but many lay still,their bodies twisted into im-
possible shapes.
FlemingThe youth looked once for Wilsonhis friend.. He saw a ve-
hement young man, powder-smeared and frowsled, whom
he knew itto be his friendhim.. AlsoThe youthfullieuten-
ant, walso, was unscathed in his position at the rear. He
had continued to curse but it was now with the air of
a man who was using his last box of oaths.
For the fire of the regiment had begun to wane
and drip. It'sThe robust voice that had come strangely
from the thin ranks, was growing rapidly weak.
